subject: Re: Tradeoff btw. right design and performance
msgSnippet: ... you ... That s exactly  what I meant by the second solution. I have a reader object that after its execute() function being called returns a result set. So
messageBody:
> What about writing while reading? Can you start reading and once
you
> got enough data you write it as XML?
>

That's exactly what I meant by the second solution. I have a reader
object that after its execute() function being called returns a
result set. So the composer actully fetches the recordsed and writes
out the read data. The benefit is that memory is allocated as lowest
amount as it needed but the disatvantage is the composer has to not
forgetting to close the reader object otherwise the DB connection is
left open.

After reading for awhile I found usefulness of MockObjects and found
that my obstacles may be overcome if I separate a too big function.
The function from inside called the reader featched the resultset and
composed the output. If I make several small subfunctions then I
could test each of them separately with help of MockObjects. But then
another question comes in. Should I test the one big public function
(that actually inside merely calls several small functions)?

Let me make up an example:

public void buildReport(ReportSpec spec, OutputStream out) {
init(spec);
ResultSet rec = reader.execute(spec);
composeData(rec, spec, out);
reader.close();
}

look at this snippet as at an logical example. I wrote an own test
for each of internal functions by using MockObjects (if needed) but
should I test buildReport function? It seems to me I'm just not able
to.

Sorry for a long question.
